coredata.dc:title: Characterization of temporal patterns of transient ischemic episodes of electrocardiogram

abstract.ce:para: In this paper, we test the hypothesis that different temporal patterns of transient changes of ST segment level (transient ischemic ST episodes) during ambulatory electrocardiographic monitoring result from different physiological mechanisms responsible for ischemia. We studied two distinctly differents sets of records chosen from the European Society of Cardiology ST-T Database: a set of records contining isolated ischemic ST episodes and a set of records containing salvos of ischemic ST episodes. We hypothesize that the isolated-episode pattern is due to sporadic physical activity in the context of increased oxygen demand, and that the salvo-episode pattern is due to vascular/endothelial factors in the context of reduced oxygen supply to coronary vasoconstrictions and vasospasms. We measured and characterized time- and frequency-domain changes of the instantaneous heart rate time series and changes in the amount of ventricular ectopy in the windows of coinciding transient ischemic episodes for both sets. For consistent spectral tracking of non-stationary instantaneous heart rate time series, and studying frequency-domain sympathetic and vagal correlates of neuro-autonomic control during transient ischemic events, we used an adaptive autoregressive technique with a recursive least-square algorithm. The observations supported our hypothesis that the isolated-episode pattern reflects demand-driven ischemia and that the salvo-episode pattern reflects supply-driven ischemia.

abstract.ce:para: In this paper, we test the hypothesis that different temporal patterns of transient changes of ST segment level (transient ischemic ST episodes) during ambulatory electrocardiographic monitoring result from different physiological mechanisms responsible for ischemia. We studied two distinctly differents sets of records chosen from the European Society of Cardiology ST-T Database: a set of records contining isolated ischemic ST episodes and a set of records containing salvos of ischemic ST episodes. We hypothesize that the isolated-episode pattern is due to sporadic physical activity in the context of increased oxygen demand, and that the salvo-episode pattern is due to vascular/endothelial factors in the context of reduced oxygen supply to coronary vasoconstrictions and vasospasms. We measured and characterized time- and frequency-domain changes of the instantaneous heart rate time series and changes in the amount of ventricular ectopy in the windows of coinciding transient ischemic episodes for both sets. For consistent spectral tracking of non-stationary instantaneous heart rate time series, and studying frequency-domain sympathetic and vagal correlates of neuro-autonomic control during transient ischemic events, we used an adaptive autoregressive technique with a recursive least-square algorithm. The observations supported our hypothesis that the isolated-episode pattern reflects demand-driven ischemia and that the salvo-episode pattern reflects supply-driven ischemia.
